article_title: Tech Disrupted Friendship. It’s Time to Bring It Back
article_summary:
Make real friends.” “AI slop.” These are just the defaced ads I noticed during my daily trips from Brooklyn to Manhattan.
People have always defaced New York subway ads in every way imaginable, but what happened with the Friend ads tapped into a deep angst about AI.
Often prone to sycophancy, bots can affirm what their users tell them and spout the kind of praise a real friend never would.
Amid all of this the tide began to shift, albeit slightly, against AI friends.

What if the mimicry of a real fireplace was responsible for reducing very real stress?
Christopher D. Lynn, professor and graduate director of anthropology at the University of Alabama, has studied the impact of viewing fire on blood pressure.
He wrote back that he “replicated our original study using an electric fireplace with funding from Napoleon Fireplaces and found results similar to the original study.” Lynn is working on getting that paper published.

article_title: The Dollar Is Facing an End to Its Dominance
article_summary:
2026 will be the year when US dollar dilution—the quiet erosion of its global dominance as countries trade and pay in alternatives—starts to build momentum.
The more Washington uses the dollar as a weapon, the more the world builds ways to circumvent it.
America’s share of global trade has fallen from one-third in 2000 to just one-quarter today.
As emerging economies trade more with each other, the dollar is less central to the flow of goods.
At the same time, central banks around the world are starting to accumulate currencies other than the dollar as reserves.

article_title: The Age of the All-Access AI Agent Is Here
article_summary:
Now, the next wave of generative AI systems are likely to want more access to your data than ever before.
While much of the initial controversy over large language models (LLMs) was the flagrant copying of copyrighted data online, AI agents’ access to your personal data will likely cause a new host of problems.
While there’s no strict definition of what an AI agent actually is, they’re often best thought of as a generative AI system or LLM that has been given some level of autonomy.
Some more advanced AI products and features provide a glimpse into how much access agents and systems could be given.
Having exhausted much of the web, many companies made it their default position to train AI systems on user data, making people opt out instead of opt in.

article_title: The Gloves Are Off in the Fight for Your Right to Repair
article_summary:
Repair advocates are planning to continue that push into 2026 and beyond, applying pressure to legislators in an attempt to give gearheads more options when it comes to the gadgets they use every day.
So, too, has Google, which redesigned its Pixel Watch to make it more repairable after pressure from repair advocates.
Despite these victories, companies continue to find ways to dance around regulations, obfuscate repair manuals, and make some repair tools available to customers only in certain states.
Repair advocates want to repeal Section 1201 of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, which prevents bypassing passwords and encryption or selling equipment that could do so.
“All of those things are not what we agreed to when we brought technology into our homes.” Despite what can feel like a constant uphill push, repair advocates are optimistic.
